cell.html: "Hot waters". When the city was first founded in 1575, it was given this name for the abundance of hot springs in the region, which still are exploited for numerous spas and for domestic use.
cell.text: "Hot waters". When the city was first founded in 1575, it was given this name for the abundance of hot springs in the region, which still are exploited for numerous spas and for domestic use.

cell.html: "Lower California". The Spanish colony of California was divided into two—upper and lower—in 1804. The Mexican territory of Upper California, or Alta California , would in 1848 become the US states of California , Nevada , Utah , and parts of Arizona and Wyoming . See also: Origin of the name California .
cell.text: "Lower California". The Spanish colony of California was divided into two—upper and lower—in 1804. The Mexican territory of Upper California, or Alta California , would in 1848 become the US states of California , Nevada , Utah , and parts of Arizona and Wyoming . See also: Origin of the name California .

cell.html: "Southern Baja California". See also: Origin of the name California .
cell.text: "Southern Baja California". See also: Origin of the name California .

cell.html: The state takes its name from the city of Campeche , which was founded in 1540 by Spanish Conquistadores as San Francisco de Campeche atop the preexisting Maya city of Canpech or Kimpech.
cell.text: The state takes its name from the city of Campeche , which was founded in 1540 by Spanish Conquistadores as San Francisco de Campeche atop the preexisting Maya city of Canpech or Kimpech.

cell.html: The state takes its name from its capital city, Chihuahua . This name is thought to derive from the Nahuatl Xicuahua , or "dry, sandy place". [ verification needed ]
cell.text: The state takes its name from its capital city, Chihuahua . This name is thought to derive from the Nahuatl Xicuahua , or "dry, sandy place". [ verification needed ]

cell.html: Origin disputed. May mean "serpent that flies" ( coatl "snake" + huila "to fly") or "place of many trees" ( quautli "trees" + la "abundance")
cell.text: Origin disputed. May mean "serpent that flies" ( coatl "snake" + huila "to fly") or "place of many trees" ( quautli "trees" + la "abundance")

cell.html: The state takes its name from its capital city, Colima .
cell.text: The state takes its name from its capital city, Colima .

cell.html: The state is named after its capital city, Durango , which was named after the city of Durango, Biscay in the Basque Country , northern Spain . During colonial times it was part of the Spanish realm of Nueva Vizcaya , "New Biscay", a province of New Spain .
cell.text: The state is named after its capital city, Durango , which was named after the city of Durango, Biscay in the Basque Country , northern Spain . During colonial times it was part of the Spanish realm of Nueva Vizcaya , "New Biscay", a province of New Spain .

cell.html: "Froghill". [ verification needed ] The state is named after its capital city, Guanajuato .
cell.text: "Froghill". [ verification needed ] The state is named after its capital city, Guanajuato .

cell.html: "Warrior". Named after Vicente Guerrero , a hero of the Mexican War of Independence and an early president of Mexico. The surname Guerrero , meaning "warrior" in Spanish, is derived from guerra "war", a Germanic loanword related to the English word war .
cell.text: "Warrior". Named after Vicente Guerrero , a hero of the Mexican War of Independence and an early president of Mexico. The surname Guerrero , meaning "warrior" in Spanish, is derived from guerra "war", a Germanic loanword related to the English word war .

cell.html: Named after Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla , considered the initiator of the Mexican War of Independence in 1810 . See also: Hidalgo (Spanish nobility)
cell.text: Named after Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla , considered the initiator of the Mexican War of Independence in 1810 . See also: Hidalgo (Spanish nobility)

cell.html: The state is named after Mexico City , itself named after the Aztec capital Mexico Tenochtitlan .
cell.text: The state is named after Mexico City , itself named after the Aztec capital Mexico Tenochtitlan .

cell.html: Named after José María Morelos , one of the leaders of Mexico's struggle against Spain during the War of Independence .
cell.text: Named after José María Morelos , one of the leaders of Mexico's struggle against Spain during the War of Independence .

cell.html: "Place of Nayar", referring to a 16th-century Cora chief [1] [2]

cell.html: "New Leon". Named after the Kingdom of Leon , one of the historical realms that formed Spain.
cell.text: "New Leon". Named after the Kingdom of Leon , one of the historical realms that formed Spain.

cell.html: The state is named after the city of Oaxaca .
cell.text: The state is named after the city of Oaxaca .

cell.html: "People". The state is named after its capital city, Puebla .
cell.text: "People". The state is named after its capital city, Puebla .

cell.html: Named after Andrés Quintana Roo , a hero from the War of Independence.
cell.text: Named after Andrés Quintana Roo , a hero from the War of Independence.

cell.html: Named after its capital city, San Luis Potosí .
cell.text: Named after its capital city, San Luis Potosí .

cell.html: Origin of name is disputed. May mean " round pitahaya " or " cut corn " [2]
cell.text: Origin of name is disputed. May mean " round pitahaya " or " cut corn " [2]

cell.html: "In the place of the corn". [ verification needed ]
cell.text: "In the place of the corn". [ verification needed ]

cell.html: "Place of Tortillas". The state is named after the capital of Tlaxcala , which is named after the pre-Columbian city-state of Tlaxcallan.
cell.text: "Place of Tortillas". The state is named after the capital of Tlaxcala , which is named after the pre-Columbian city-state of Tlaxcallan.

cell.html: "True Cross". The state is named after the port of Veracruz . This name was given to the first Spanish city in New Spain by Hernán Cortés in 1519 , in the form La Villa Rica de la Vera Cruz , "The Rich Village of the True Cross".
cell.text: "True Cross". The state is named after the port of Veracruz . This name was given to the first Spanish city in New Spain by Hernán Cortés in 1519 , in the form La Villa Rica de la Vera Cruz , "The Rich Village of the True Cross".

cell.html: The (probably apocryphal ) story goes that when the Spaniards first waded ashore on the Yucatán Peninsula, they asked the members of the local population, who were watching, "What is this place?" The local indígenas, not understanding Spanish, asked "What did you say?" (Yuca-hatlanás?). The Spanish assumed that anyone would understand their language, and took it to be the name. Another legend has it that when Spaniards asked a local native "Where are we?", the native answered "Yuc Atan", meaning "I'm not from here", which Spaniards assumed as the name of the place.
cell.text: The (probably apocryphal ) story goes that when the Spaniards first waded ashore on the Yucatán Peninsula, they asked the members of the local population, who were watching, "What is this place?" The local indígenas, not understanding Spanish, asked "What did you say?" (Yuca-hatlanás?). The Spanish assumed that anyone would understand their language, and took it to be the name. Another legend has it that when Spaniards asked a local native "Where are we?", the native answered "Yuc Atan", meaning "I'm not from here", which Spaniards assumed as the name of the place.

cell.html: "People from the Place of Grass". The state is named after its capital city, Zacatecas . The city was originally called Villa de Nuestra Señora de los Zacatecas , "House of Our Lady of the Zacatecs".
cell.text: "People from the Place of Grass". The state is named after its capital city, Zacatecas . The city was originally called Villa de Nuestra Señora de los Zacatecas , "House of Our Lady of the Zacatecs".

context.text: Mexican state name etymologies - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
State name Language of origin Source word Meaning and Notes
This article provides a collection of the etymologies of the names of the states of Mexico .
Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources . Unverifiable material may be challenged and removed.
This article does not cite any references or sources . (February 2007)
^ Nayarit . Tour by Mexico. Retrieved on 2007 - 08-07 . ^ El Nayar . Enciclopedia de los Municipios de M xico . Archived from the original on 2007 - 05-02 . Retrieved on 2007 - 08-07 .

entity.htmlSnippet:
State nameLanguage of originSource wordMeaning and Notes
AguascalientesSpanishaguas calientes"Hot waters". When the city was first founded in 1575, it was given this name for the abundance of hot springs in the region, which still are exploited for numerous spas and for domestic use.
Baja CaliforniaSpanish"Lower California". The Spanish colony of California was divided into two—upper and lower—in 1804. The Mexican territory of Upper California, or Alta California, would in 1848 become the US states of California, Nevada, Utah, and parts of Arizona and Wyoming. See also: Origin of the name California.
Baja California SurSpanish"Southern Baja California". See also: Origin of the name California.
Campeche ? ?The state takes its name from the city of Campeche, which was founded in 1540 by Spanish Conquistadores as San Francisco de Campeche atop the preexisting Maya city of Canpech or Kimpech.
ChihuahuaNahuatlxicuahua[verification needed]The state takes its name from its capital city, Chihuahua. This name is thought to derive from the Nahuatl Xicuahua, or "dry, sandy place".[verification needed]
ChiapasNahuatlChi(y)apan
CoahuilaNahuatlOrigin disputed. May mean "serpent that flies" (coatl "snake" + huila "to fly") or "place of many trees" (quautli "trees" + la "abundance")
ColimaNahuatlColimanThe state takes its name from its capital city, Colima.
DurangoBasqueThe state is named after its capital city, Durango, which was named after the city of Durango, Biscay in the Basque Country, northern Spain. During colonial times it was part of the Spanish realm of Nueva Vizcaya, "New Biscay", a province of New Spain.
GuanajuatoP'urhépechaQuanax Huato[verification needed]"Froghill".[verification needed] The state is named after its capital city, Guanajuato.
GuerreroSpanish"Warrior". Named after Vicente Guerrero, a hero of the Mexican War of Independence and an early president of Mexico. The surname Guerrero, meaning "warrior" in Spanish, is derived from guerra "war", a Germanic loanword related to the English word war.
HidalgoSpanishNamed after Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla, considered the initiator of the Mexican War of Independence in 1810. See also: Hidalgo (Spanish nobility)
JaliscoNahuatlXālixco"Place with sand on the ground" [1]
MéxicoNahuatlMēxihcoThe state is named after Mexico City, itself named after the Aztec capital Mexico Tenochtitlan.
MichoacánNahuatlMichhuahcān"Place of possessors of fish".
MorelosSpanishNamed after José María Morelos, one of the leaders of Mexico's struggle against Spain during the War of Independence.
NayaritCora"Place of Nayar", referring to a 16th-century Cora chief[1][2]
Nuevo LeónSpanish"New Leon". Named after the Kingdom of Leon, one of the historical realms that formed Spain.
OaxacaNahuatlHuāxyacacThe state is named after the city of Oaxaca.
PueblaSpanish"People". The state is named after its capital city, Puebla.
QuerétaroP'urhépecha ? ?
Quintana RooSpanishNamed after Andrés Quintana Roo, a hero from the War of Independence.
San Luis PotosíSpanishNamed after its capital city, San Luis Potosí.
Sinaloa ? ?Origin of name is disputed. May mean "round pitahaya" or "cut corn" [2]
SonoraOpata[verification needed]xunuta[verification needed]"In the place of the corn".[verification needed]
TabascoNahuatl ?"Flooded earth".[verification needed]
TamaulipasNahuatl ?"Place with high mountains".[verification needed]
TlaxcalaNahuatlTlaxcallān"Place of Tortillas". The state is named after the capital of Tlaxcala, which is named after the pre-Columbian city-state of Tlaxcallan.
VeracruzSpanishvera cruz"True Cross". The state is named after the port of Veracruz. This name was given to the first Spanish city in New Spain by Hernán Cortés in 1519, in the form La Villa Rica de la Vera Cruz, "The Rich Village of the True Cross".
Yucatán ? ?The (probably apocryphal) story goes that when the Spaniards first waded ashore on the Yucatán Peninsula, they asked the members of the local population, who were watching, "What is this place?" The local indígenas, not understanding Spanish, asked "What did you say?" (Yuca-hatlanás?). The Spanish assumed that anyone would understand their language, and took it to be the name. Another legend has it that when Spaniards asked a local native "Where are we?", the native answered "Yuc Atan", meaning "I'm not from here", which Spaniards assumed as the name of the place.
ZacatecasNahuatlzacatēcah"People from the Place of Grass". The state is named after its capital city, Zacatecas. The city was originally called Villa de Nuestra Señora de los Zacatecas, "House of Our Lady of the Zacatecs".
